dialogue_line_replacements.text: Sí, esta otra es más barata — quince euros.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: Yes, this other one is cheaper — fifteen euros.
I'll take it. Do you accept card?

dialogue_line_replacements.text: Gracias. Aquí tiene el cambio — cinco euros.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: Thank you. Here's your change — five euros.

cultural_notes_overrides.formality: Spain uses euros. 'Me lo quedo' is more common than 'me lo llevo' in Spain for 'I'll take it'. VAT (IVA) is included in displayed prices — no surprise at the till. Sales (rebajas) happen in January and July and are major shopping events.
cultural_notes_overrides.gestures: In Spain, pointing at a specific item in a display case is perfectly normal and not rude — vendors expect it. 'Pónmelo/la' (put it for me) is a common way to order or buy something casual.
cultural_notes_overrides.regional_variations: In Spain 'vale' (okay/sounds good) is used constantly in shopping transactions: '¿Me la envuelves? Vale, perfecto.' Spain's online shopping culture is large — El Corte Inglés and Zara are iconic domestic brands.
cultural_notes_overrides.distincion: Currency-related /θ/ words: 'precio' [ˈpɾeθjo], 'descuento' no /θ/ issue. But 'céntimos' [ˈθentimos] (cents) features the Castilian /θ/ distinctly.
